awd_titl_txt: The Langlands Conjectures for Connected and Disconnected Groups
awd_abstract_narration:
This project investigates facets of the Langlands program -- an area of Mathematics bridging number theory and geometry that examines in a systematic way the symmetries inherent in solutions of algebraic equations. By relating these symmetries to geometry, the program creates a powerful way of obtaining arithmetic information. The project is particularly concerned with obtaining such information explicitly. Deep and explicit knowledge of the arithmetic of numbers is in turn essential for many technological advances over the last decades that we take for granted today, including encryption and digital security.

In more detail, the project will establish a uniform and explicit construction of the refined local Langlands correspondence, for general connected reductive p-adic groups splitting over a tame extension and all supercuspidal parameters, in residual characteristic prime to the order of the Weyl group. The project further aims to compare the result of this construction with other more general but less explicit constructions, such as the one of Genestier-Lafforgue for local function fields. The role of disconnected groups will also be considered.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: The Langlands program has been at the forefront of major developments in number theory, such as Langlands’ proof of cases of the Artin conjecture, Wiles’ proof of the Taniyama-Shimura conjecture, or Taylor’s proof of the Sato-Tate conjecture, and is intimately linked to the Gan-Gross-Prasad conjectures. It is an active area of research, and recent advances in harmonic analysis and arithmetic geometry due to Ngo, Arthur, Fargues, and Scholze, havepaved the way formajor new developments. The PI's contributions to this program over the period of the award were:
  1. In collaboration with J. Fintzen and L. Spice, a correction of the construction of supercuspidal representations due to J.K.Yu.
  2. An explicit construction of the refined local Langlands correspondence for arbitrary supercuspidal parameters of p-adic groups, with a small condition on p.
  3. In collaboration with J. Fintzen and L. Spice, reinterpretation of Spice's character formula for regular supercuspidal representations.
  4. In collaboration with J. Fintzen and L. Spice, a proof of stability and endoscopic character identities for regular supercuspidal L-packets, as well as many cases for general supercuspidal L-packets.
  5. A definition of a new fundamental group for reductive groups over local fields, and the study of the resulting covers and their relationship to the Langlands principle of functoriality.
  6. A formulation of Langlands conjectures in the setting of disconnected reductive groups over local fields.
Broader Impact: The PI is actively engaged with young mathematicians at various levels, from undergraduate students to post-docs, is a long-standing member and currently a chair of the Michigan REU committee, has mentored several REU projects, developed new undergraduate and graduate level classes and seminars, hosted international graduate students, and organized workshops and summer schools with high participation of graduate students. More precisely, the following synergistic activities have taken place during the time of the award.
  1. In collaboration with G. Prasad, the PI wrote a comprehensive book (750 pages) on Bruhat-Tits theory, aimed both at beginners and experts. It contains a self-contained treatment, including over 100 pages of background material, as well as most modern developments of the theory.
  2. In collaboration with Y. Sakellaridis, W. T. Gan, and P.-H. Chaudouard, the PI organized a summer school on the Langlands program in 2022, spanning 3 weeks and featuring 31 invited speakers and over 100 participants, mostly graduate students and post-docs.
  3. In collaboration with Y. Sakellaridis and R. Beuzart-Plessis, the PI organized a weekly Zoom seminar between January 2021 and May 2022, with attendance from around the globe, featuring a mix of research and expository talks.
  4. The PI has given multiple expository lecture series geared at graduate students and post-docs, including lecture series on the Arthur-Selberg trace formula and its stabilization at IMS in 2018, and IHES 2022, as well as lectures in the RaMpAgE and Automorphic Project online seminars in 2021. The PI has also written two sets of lecture notes on the Arthur-Selberg trace formula, to accompany these lecture series.
  5. The PI has been a long-standing member of the REU committee at Michigan, and is currently serving as the chair of that committee. In addition, the PI has ran two successful REU projects, one in 2018, and one in collaboration with K. Koziol in 2021.
  6. The PI has supervised 3 graduate students and 5 post-docs at the University of Michigan, has hosted a visiting graduate student for an extended period of time, and has mentored through discussions and multiple graduate students at other institutions.
  7. The PI has organized learning seminars at the University of Michigan.
  8. The PI has organized a workshop at Oberwolfach 2021 together with G. Chenevier, S. Kudla, and S. Morel, and a workshop Banff 2021 together with J. Arthur and J. Gordon.
